body:
Yeah this is a good point, though I'm not sure stating that processor's `close()` call should NOT close the stores that maybe re-used during rebalance is a good approach. Since:

1. We still cannot programmatically prevent users from calling `store.close()`.
2. User implementing the `Processor` API would probably not know anything about "rebalancing" and "processor re-usage" at all.

Instead, I'd suggest we change the javadoc to sth. like "users only need to implement this function but NEVER need to call this api explicitly since they will be triggered by the library automatically when necessary". AND update the examples to remove the close calls. This is true since in `ProcessorStateManager` we will close the stores after the whole topology (i.e. all nodes) has been closed, which is actually the right ordering.
BTW could we update the title to `KAFKA-4919: ...` as well? @dguy

@hachikuji adjusted to using a parameter as discussed (at least I hope so :))

Test is perfectly stable with this solution too (eventually OOMing only)
![oomeventually](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6490959/24215848/66db6dbe-0f3a-11e7-9e1f-d41a3460eec4.png)
Thanks @ewencp I will try to explicitly set these logs for collection and see if it works.
@enothereska @dguy comments addressed
LGTM and merged to trunk/0.10.2.
LGTM and merged to 0.10.2.

I would even go further, and change the interface, ie, split it up into two. Users implement the full interface, but only get the limited interface when the get at store to work with. We would need a KIP for this, but I think it should be "straight forward" and worth the effort. Just relying on the JavaDocs is something I don't like too much.

@ijuma yea looks like it is. Should I look into that here?

@ijuma Note: This is not caused by the NPE. Fixed the NPE, but still get the OOM. It appears closing the consumer after that test is dead locked (if you were to add it in the last line). Looking into this.
@dguy Could you manually close these PRs against 0.10.2? Thanks!
@mjsax How about track it as a separate JIRA, and accept this as a near-term fix since we do not know how long that refactoring will take or if it will make it in 0.11.0?

@ijuma this happens because `MockTime` never advances and hence the loop in `org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.ConsumerNetworkClient#poll(org.apache.kafka.clients.consumer.internals.RequestFuture<?>, long)` goes on forever.

Hi @benstopford. Yes, I'd like to continue this. I just haven't managed to find the time.

The code hasn't been touched for 8-ish months, so of course I'll need to update it. I may decide to break this up into a series of smaller diffs, possibly adding auto-generation to one section at a time. That may make this more manageable. I'll see what I need to do, once I get back to this code.
@guozhangwang Thanks!

Test with JDK 8 and Scala 2.11 failed because `KafkaStreamsTest.testCannotStartOnceClosed` took more 2+ hours before it is killed. `./gradlew -PscalaVersion=2.11 streams:test --tests org.apache.kafka.streams.KafkaStreamsTest` works on my machine. Thus the failure is probably not caused by this patch. All system tests have passed. See https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder-2/210.
@ijuma @hachikuji fixes for NPE and leaking threads (from failing to close the consumer in this test) added.

![noleaks](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6490959/24219696/ff94e546-0f47-11e7-8a29-18c929e82d0e.png)

goes on literally forever now without slowing down

LGTM and I like the idea of adding a warning to the  `StoreState.close` javadocs.  I would go further and make a note in the release notes and documentation.  It took me a while to figure out what was going on and other may be in the same boat and the release notes is where one would naturally look for any API semantic changes in the new release.  Might also want to update the `Processor.close` javadocs to be clearer about what kind of resources one is expected to close there.
Tested by generating the docs. LGTM. Thank you for fixing this.

Sorry, I had to rebase again as there were a lot of conflicts among my commits and among mine and other commits. I deprecated  
```
StreamConfig.TIMESTAMP_EXTRACTOR_CLASS_CONFIG
StreamConfig.TIMESTAMP_EXTRACTOR_CLASS_DOC
StreamConfig.KEY_SERDE_CLASS_CONFIG
StreamConfig.KEY_SERDE_CLASS_DOC
StreamConfig.VALUE_SERDE_CLASS_CONFIG
StreamConfig.VALUE_SERDE_CLASS_DOC
StreamConfig.keySerde()
StreamConfig.valueSerde()
```

For test classes, I replaced the deprecated variables with new ones. For non-test classes, I put an if condition to check both of the variables.
@guozhangwang @enothereska - i noticed this was creating a lot of noise in the logs i'm trying to debug. There is no point in logging the exception every time

@mjsax we would need to change our hierarchy somewhat, i.e., `KeyValueStore` and `WindowStore` won't be able to extend `StateStore`, the implementations of these interfaces would need to implement StateStore.  So this kind-of works for our maintained implementations, but doesn't really work for custom stores. Also, there is nothing to stop anyone from casting to the Impl if they really want.

That said, i still think we should do something to restrict this. Just not as part of this PR.
